ISSUE.TITLE: podman stop -t -1 container-id issue
ISSUE.DESCRIPTION: ### Issue Description The online [documentation](https://docs.podman.io/en/stable/markdown/podman-stop.1.html) for podman stop command says ``` --time, -t=seconds Seconds to wait before forcibly stopping the container. Use -1 for infinite wait. ``` However using -1 as timeout shows overflow or a 64bit unsigned integer and results in an immediate SIGKILL ``` $ podman stop -t -1 indimail-mta WARN[0000] StopSignal SIGTERM failed to stop container indimail-mta in 18446744073709551615 seconds, resorting to SIGKILL indimail-mta ``` ### Steps to reproduce the issue Steps to reproduce the issue 1. start any container 2. stop the container using `podman stop -1 container-id` ### Describe the results you received immediate SIGKILL of the container ### Describe the results you expected Specifying -1 should result in letting the container stop when all processes stop ### podman info output ```yaml host: arch: amd64 buildahVersion: 1.33.5 cgroupControllers: - BUGGYCOMMIT.MESSAGE: Merge pull request #21594 from arixmkii/qemu-win-machine-5 Change QEMU netdev to Unix domain socket

COMMIT.MESSAGE: Fix podman stop -t -1 CID Currently if a user specifies a negative time to stop a container the code ends up specifying the negative time to time.Duration which treats it as 0. By settine the default to max.Unint32 we end up with a positive number which indicates > 68 years which is probably close enough to infinity for our use case. Fixes: https://github.com/containers/podman/issues/21811 Signed-off-by: Daniel J Walsh <dwalsh@redhat.com>
